subject: JUnit patch for Mock objects
msgSnippet: I have knocked together a patch for JUnit 3.7 which enables you to - in effect - pick up mock objects from your CLASSPATH - i.e. you do not need to do anything
messageBody:
I have knocked together a patch for JUnit 3.7 which enables you to - in
effect - pick up mock objects from your CLASSPATH - i.e. you do not need to
do anything special to get mock objects to be used by the code - it just
works. The patch enables you to specify which mock objects are loaded on a
per Test class basis. E.g. if in TestA, you want the code to use a mock "C"
implementation, but in TestB you want to use a real "C" implementation then
this can be achieved with the patch.

This works without having to write your "real" code in any special way -
i.e. you don't have to write the code to support the tests.

Below is a description of how to set up and use the patch to give you a
flavour of how it works. If anyone is interested in receiving it, just send
me a mail and I'll send it to you...



Patch instructions:

In your junit3.7 directory replace the existing junit.jar with the patched
one.

Some notes:

1) This only works if you have dynamic reloading switched on (which
should be default anyway)
2) To use, add the directory where you mock objects are as a -D
parameter, i.e.

java
-Djunit.mockpath=c:\path-to-my-mock-objects junit.swingui.TestRunner

3) The mock objects directory should *not* be in your CLASSPATH
4) In the directory where you keep your tests create a properties file
for each test, e.g. if you have a class called TestB, then you have a
properties file called TestB.properties. Each line in the file looks like
this:

included.<n>=<class name>

Where <n> is a unique integer (make sure it is unique or you'll get
strange results!), and <class name> is the name of a class that you want
loaded from the mock objects directory.
5) Make sure that you have the directory containing the head of the
package structure that contains your properties file in your CLASSPATH,
e.g. if you have a properties file for class mypackage.TestMyClass
stored in the following file:
c:\javadev\mypackage\TestMyClass.properties

Then you should have the following in your CLASSPATH:
c:\javadev

Thats all

Matt
